newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Petron rejects review of Aramco crude deal.
newsitem.headline: Petron rejects review of Aramco crude deal.

text.p: Petron Corp, the Philippines' biggest oil refiner, said on Wednesday it will not be able to immediately conduct a review of its crude supply pact with its shareholder Saudi Arabia's Aramco because it would violate their contract.

"I believe that we should allow present provisions to take place and a review should be made at the appropriate time, otherwise we would be violating our contract with our partner," Petron Chairman Monico Jacob told the House of Representatives committee on energy.
Jacob said the contract with Aramco provides for a review of the agreement in 1999 and every five years.
The House energy committee started on Wednesday public hearings to determine the truth of the allegations that the Aramco crude supply pact is not beneficial to Petron.
Earlier, some officials of Philippine National Oil Co (PNOC) called for a review of the crude supply pact that required Petron to source a substantial portion of its crude from Aramco.
The officials said the arrangement may no longer be advantageous to the oil refiner with the full deregulation of the industry.
Aramco bought 40 percent equity of Petron Corp in 1994 from the government's PNOC which still owns 40 percent of the company. The remaining 20 percent is owned by the public.
